column7: A market leader in online employment marketplaces. A multinational presence spanning Australia, New Zealand, Hong Kong, Southeast East Asia, Brazil and Mexico. In addition, SEEK has minority investments in China, South Korea and several other countries.

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: SEEK was founded in 1997, headquartered in Melbourne, Australia, and listed on the ASX. It operates businesses in Australia, New Zealand, Southeast Asia, Hong Kong and Latin America.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: 1 July 2022 to 30 June 2023 (FY2023) Frequency: annual Reported date: 7 September 2023 Contact point: sustainability@seek.com.au
Not Applicable

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: Principal activities SEEK's primary activities consist of online matching of hirers and candidates with career opportunities and other related services. SEEK also has an economic interest in the SEEK Growth Fund (the Fund), a unit trust holding investments in a portfolio of high-growth human capital management industry investments. SEEK Continuing Operations Continuing Operations includes SEEK's employment marketplaces, select portfolio investments and SEEK's equity-accounted investment in the Fund.\t

As of the end of FY2023, SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs APAC workforce comprised 3,068 employees, with a roughly equal distribution across the ANZ and Asia regions. Most employees were employed permanently, with 6% used on either a fixed-term or casual basis. Full-time employees account for 96% of the workforce, with part-time employees comprising 4% across APAC. In addition to the APAC business, SEEK has companies in Brazil and Mexico that operate under the Catho and OCCMundial brands. The workforce profile table below also includes the data for the LATAM business.

Annualised voluntary attrition was 11%, and total annualised attrition was 13% across APAC. It represents a significant decrease compared to prior years and reflects the changing sentiment within the technology sector.

The Board, through the Audit and Risk Management Committee (ARMC), oversees and manages non-financial risks, including ESG risks, and approves internal Risk Appetite Statements. All directors receive the ARMC papers and generally attend the meetings; the outcomes of the meetings are then reported to the Board.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: The Nomination Committee undertakes Board succession planning. To fill vacancies or where a need for an additional director has been identified, the Nomination Committee identifies suitable candidates who bring specific skills to complement the existing Board. Where appropriate, external search consultants may be engaged to assist.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Graham Goldsmith became Chairman in January 2019, serving for six years on the Board and as Chairman of the Audit and Risk Management Committee.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: The Board, through the Audit and Risk Management Committee (ARMC), oversees and manages non-financial risks, including ESG risks, and approves internal Risk Appetite Statements. All directors receive the ARMC papers and generally attend the meetings; the outcomes of the meetings are then reported to the Board. The Board also devotes time to material ESG risks and opportunities and receives periodic updates on emerging ESG matters relevant to SEEK.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: The Board also devotes time to material ESG risks and opportunities and receives periodic updates on emerging ESG matters relevant to SEEK. The Board governs and approves SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂPrincipal risksÃ¢ÂÂ and, after consideration of stakeholder expectations, agrees on the ESG reporting topics and this report. SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂEnvironment and communityÃ¢ÂÂ risk is a current example of an ESG-related principal risk.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: The MD and CEO have delegated responsibility for managing the business, including ESG risks and opportunities. The Chief Financial Officer (CFO) is accountable for sustainability reporting, supported by senior management working in critical areas of ESG risk and employees with specialist ESG skills. The executive responsible for the subject matter reviews the report to confirm the accuracy and completeness of the information provided. The information in this report is validated by subject matter experts and senior management and is supported by verifiable evidence.

The Board requires that non-executive directors bring views and judgement to Board deliberations independent of management or any substantial shareholder and free from interests, positions or other relationships that could interfere with the exercise of independent judgment. Its Director Independence Guidelines set out the BoardÃ¢ÂÂs approach to assessing independence.

The foundation of SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs Whistleblower Protection Policy is the commitment to whistleblowers to protect them from reprisal and other detriment. The policy intends to encourage employees and stakeholders to report concerns of wrongdoing. It explains how to speak up, what protections a person who registers wrongdoing will receive and SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs processes for dealing with reports of misconduct.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: The Board skills and experience matrix is used to inform the directorsÃ¢ÂÂ continuing education program, as it provides insight into whether any skills or experience gaps can be addressed through further education. To assist directors in understanding SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs strategic and business objectives, the Board and individual directors occasionally visit SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs various overseas operations.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column7: The Board reviews its performance each year, including assessing the operation of the Board and committees, as well as Board reporting and processes. The Board performance review aims to ensure that individual directors and the Board work effectively in meeting the responsibilities described in the Board and Committee Charters.

SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs executive remuneration framework has been in place for 11 years. It is structured so that, aside from Base Salary and Superannuation, executives and other senior leaders receive their equity remuneration through the EEP and WSP rather than cash.

The executive remuneration structure, including the significant weighting towards equity, is guided by SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs remuneration objectives, which support SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs focus on building a sustainable business over the long term (see section 3.1). The quantum of executive remuneration is guided by several inputs, one of which is external benchmarking. Other inputs include the competitive landscape for executive talent, internal relativities, and the individualÃ¢ÂÂs experience and performance.
The MD and CEO remuneration proportion is 28% from base salary and superannuation, 15% from EEP equity rights, and 57% from WSP options and rights.\t

During the past year, as we continued to monitor and adapt to variable market conditions, we remained focused on achieving our purpose and creating long-term value. It includes our commitment to positively impacting the communities in which we operate. Reporting our efforts on this ensures we are accountable for our performance and progress against that commitment.

SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs stakeholder engagement on ESG matters is wide-ranging. The main channels for external engagement are annual corporate reporting, including this report, the Annual Report, the Modern Slavery Statement, Corporate Governance Statement and Tax Transparency Report.

The Board is accountable to shareholders for SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs performance. The Board meets regularly to set strategy, monitor risk and review SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs performance and progress against its strategic direction and business plans.

The policy intends to encourage employees and stakeholders to report concerns of wrongdoing. It explains how to speak up, what protections a person who registers wrongdoing will receive and SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs processes for dealing with reports of misconduct.

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column7: The channel for shareholders to access information about SEEK is the Ã¢ÂÂAbout SEEKÃ¢ÂÂ section of the SEEK website, which provides general information about SEEK.

SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs Code of Conduct outlines the behaviours expected of employees in performing their roles and interacting with SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs customers and communities. More detailed Workplace Behaviour Guidelines and SEEK policies operate in conjunction with the Code of Conduct and, together with Our SEEK, set out the expectations for how all employees work. The Board is informed of any material breaches of the Code of Conduct.

External ratings and industry benchmarking initiatives help SEEK continually improve its sustainability performance. SEEK is covered by rating agencies and ESG analysts, including MSCI, Sustainalytics, ACSI, FTSE4Good, ISS ESG and Dow Jones Sustainability Indices (S&P Global CSA). SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs reporting reflects the following voluntary sustainability initiatives: the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI), the United Nations SDGs, the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) and the Business for Societal Impact.

Stakeholders provide valuable insights into SEEK's expectations and inform SEEKÃ¢ÂÂs ESG priorities and reporting.
